name: Upgrading the Microsoft Outlook Add-In
title: Upgrading the Microsoft Outlook Add-In
body:
This article provides guidance on upgrading the Microsoft Outlook add-In to the latest version.

Manual Desktop Installation

  • The installation process is a simple click-through installer delivered in an .exe package.
  • To run the installer, you must have admin privileges on the target machine. Local admin rights are sufficient.

Silent Install

An MSI package that can be deployed silently via a command line or by using deployment tools such as SCCM.

Command Line (msiexec)

The default command for installing the MSI via a command line is:

  • msiexec /i "EgressEmailProtection.msi"

The default command for uninstalling is:

  • msiexec /x "EgressEmailProtection.msi"

You can add other parameters, such as /quiet, as required.

Command Line Switches

The MSI has several switches that can be set with the "msiexec" command to enable or disable certain features.

Flag Function Values Default Value
BYPASSOUTLOOKCHECK Bypass checking whether MS Outlook is open for fresh installs only and not upgrades. If upgrading from 21.06, this flag will work. Note: This switch does not apply to removing older versions, and Outlook must be closed in that scenario. Set these properties to something other than white space, such as "1", in order to bypass checks <<white-space>>
INSTALLADDINKEYS Installs add-in keys (above) for all users on the machine Note: Users should use this key with the value “None” when installing Citrix.

"AllUsers"

"CurrentUser"

"None"

 "AllUsers"

Msiexec Install Command

Installing the Microsoft Outlook add-in requires the below install command:

  • msiexec /i "EgressEmailProtection.msi" /quiet

Deployment Tools

Deployment tools such as Microsoft SCCM or Tivoli can be used to deploy the Outlook client to a large group of users in a controlled way.

Group Policy Deployment

To deploy the MSI package via group policy, add or update the package within the Computer Configuration section within the group policy by following the steps below:

Note: It is very important that the path to the MSI file is not local or run through a network drive. Instead, it should be through a network share, accessible from everywhere in your network and everyone should have at least Read permissions.

  1. Load the Group Policy Management console.

  2. Right-click Group Policy Objects and select New.

  3. Open the group policy object editor.
  4. Expand Computer Configuration Software Settings.

  5. Right-click Software Settings and select Software Installation New Package…

  6. Point to the EgressEmailProtection.msi file.
  7. Under Deployment Method, select Advanced. If you choose another option, you won't be able to apply an MST if required.
  8. Add a name for the package for easy identification.

Once the group policy object is created, you will need to apply it to the relevant AD groups so that it is installed on user machines.

ADMX Template

The preferred method for deploying the Microsoft Outlook client registry keys is by utilizing ADMX templates within a Group Policy. These template files contain various user-level registry settings that control the behavior of the Microsoft Outlook desktop client.

Ensure that the ADMX template files have been placed in the relevant location. Typically, this is:

  • ADMX: C:\Windows\PolicyDefinitions
  • ADML: C:\Windows\PolicyDefinitions\en-us

The Microsoft Outlook client is highly configurable and different configurations not listed above can be controlled by command line switches and/or registry settings. As well as user settings, the client ADMX templates can apply machine-based policies such as the Gateway settings or SSO configuration.

VDI Installation or Deploying in Hidden Mode

This section will cover the work involved in environments such as:

  • Microsoft RDS
  • Citrix
  • General hot-desk or terminal server environments

If you need to deploy to specific users in any of the above environments, you will need to deploy the add-in in a hidden state by default and then enable it using user-level registry keys. This action is common for organizations that haven’t purchased a site-wide license where users do not have their own dedicated physical machines.

Authentication Prerequisites

A token is stored within the local data. This token is refreshed daily to keep the user signed in. In doing so, the following folder paths must be persistent. The folder will depend on the environment you are configured to:

  • AppData\Local\egress\6\switch.egress.com
  • AppData\Local\egress\6\us1.esi.egress.com
  • AppData\Local\egress\6\eu1.esi.egress.com
  • For on-premise or separate hosted ESIs, replace the respective end folder with the hostname

If users roam between multiple servers, an additional registry key must be applied to ensure they remain logged in when switching between them. This requirement is due to the login token is device-specific. If a user switches from Server A and then to Server B, they will be required to log in again.

To prevent this issue, the following registry key must be applied.

Location:

  • HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE \Software \Egress\Switch
  • HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE \Software\Wow6432node\Egress\Switch

Registry Key:

  • REG_SZ (String) with the name: DeviceID
  • Value: profile

Not all users may require the Microsoft Outlook add-in. For some users, the add-in must be installed in the disabled format and then targeted for specific users.

Msiexec Install

Install can be performed by via GPO, SCCM, or other deployment tools.

Msiexec Installed in Hidden Mode

Install with the following Command:

  • msiexec /i "EgressEmailProtection.msi" /quiet INSTALLADDINKEYS='None'

Show Add-In for Targeted Users

To show the plugin for specific users, the following registry keys are required:

  • [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection]
  • "LoadBehavior"=dword:00000003
  • "Manifest"=' file:///C:\Program Files (x86)\Egress Email Protection\EmailProtection.vsto|vstolocal'

If GPO is required for registry key push out, please follow the guidance below for GPO only install from step two onwards.

GPO Only Install

To install for GPO, follow the steps below:

  1. Create a new GPO with the new Microsoft Outlook client and add the MST to the modification tab. This action will install the add-in in the disabled format.

  2. Ensure the ADMX templates have been added. Once the templates are in place, right-click the group policy and select Edit. Follow this path: User Configuration Administrative Templates Egress Settings.

  3. A list of policy options will be displayed in this folder.

  4. In most cases, to enable the client for certain users, it is recommended you configure each of the following options and set their actions as below:

    • Email Resiliency - To force Microsoft Outlook to always load the Microsoft Outlook add-in and prevent users from disabling it, the value should be set to 1.

    • Load Behavior Add-in - This setting will load and enable the Microsoft Outlook add-in. It should be set to 3.

    • Manifest Outlook Add-in - Loads the Microsoft Outlook add-in manifest file. This setting should be set to:
      • file///C:\Program Files (x86)\Egress Email Protection\EmailProtection.vsto|vstolocal

If there is a mixture of 32-bit and 64-bit machines, use WMI filtering or Item-Level Targeting to apply the correct path based on the OS bitness.

Once the appropriate policy definitions have been defined, ensure that your GPO is saved, linked to the right domain, and applied to the relevant AD security group.

FAQs

The most common questions or issues about upgrading the Microsoft Outlook add-in are addressed below.

  1. The naming convention has been updated from Egress.Switch to EgressEmailProtection for where the LoadBehavior & Manifest keys reside:
    1. HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection
    2. HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection
  2. To ensure the plugin stays enabled, the following keys should be pushed out by the admin:
    • EgressEmailProtection
      • Value: 1
      • Type: String
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\office\16.0\outlook\Resiliency\AddinList]
    • LoadBehavior
      • Value: 3
      • Type: DWORD
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection]
    • EgressEmailProtection
      • Value: 1
      • Type: DWORD
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\DoNotDisableAddinList]
    • EgressEmailProtection\dtype
      • Value: 0
      • Type: DWORD
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\NotificationReminderAddinData]
    • EgressEmailProtection
      • Value: 967a844d
      • Type: DWORD
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\NotificationReminderAddinData]

images.alt:
The image displays the Microsoft Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) for the `saml2.local` domain.

A modal dialog box, titled **"New GPO,"** is overlaid on the main console window. This dialog prompts the user to define a new Group Policy Object.

**UI Elements and Input Values within the "New GPO" dialog:**

1.  **Name:** Text input field containing the value **"Egress Client."**
2.  **Source Starter GPO:** Drop-down menu currently set to the default value **"(none)."**
3.  **Action Buttons:** **OK** and **Cancel**.

**Context (Background GPMC Console):**

The left navigation pane of the GPMC shows the structure for the Forest `saml2.local`. The expandable node structure includes `Domains/saml2.local`, with sub-folders such as `Default Domain Policy`, `Domain Controllers`, `Microsoft Exchange Security`, `Group Policy Objects`, `WMI Filters`, and `Starter GPOs`. The action context implies that a new GPO is being created within the `saml2.local` domain structure.

li>

Right-click Group Policy Objects and select New.

images.alt:
The image displays the **Group Policy Management Editor** interface, utilizing a standard Windows Management Console (MMC) structure.

**Application Context:**
The interface is configuring a Group Policy Object (GPO) named **"Egress Client [DOM2.SAML2.LOCAL]"**.

**Navigation Pane (Left):**
The hierarchy is expanded to show the selected path within the GPO:
`Computer Configuration > Policies > Software Settings > Software installation`

**Active UI Interaction:**
A context (right-click) menu is active on the **"Software installation"** node.

**Menu Structure and Action:**
1.  The primary context menu shows options including **New**, View, Paste, Refresh, Export List..., Properties, and Help.
2.  The **"New"** option is selected, triggering a flyout menu.
3.  The flyout menu contains the item **"Package..."**, which is highlighted, indicating the imminent action to open the dialog for specifying a new software installation package via Group Policy.

**Details Pane (Right):**
The right pane, displaying the contents of the selected policy node, is currently empty, showing the message: **"There are no items to show in this view."** The columns visible are Name, Version, Deployment st..., and Source.
images.context: d select Software Installation New Package…

images.alt:
This image displays the Microsoft Group Policy Management Editor (GPE) console interface.

**UI Elements and Context:**

*   **Menu Bar:** Contains standard Windows navigation menus: `File`, `Action`, `View`, and `Help`.
*   **Toolbar:** Features standard Group Policy navigation and function icons.
*   **Navigation Pane (Tree View):** The left pane shows the hierarchical structure of the policy settings.

**Text and Hierarchy (Policy Path):**

The displayed context is the `Default Domain Policy [DOM2.SAML2.LOCAL] Policy`.

The navigation path is expanded down to the following folders:

1.  `User Configuration`
2.  `Policies`
3.  `Administrative Templates: Policy definition`

The folder **`Egress Settings`** is the currently selected item, highlighted within the list of Administrative Templates sub-folders (which include `Desktop`, `Control Panel`, `Network`, `System`, etc.).

This image displays the "Egress Settings" configuration dialog box, structured as a two-pane interface common in Windows management tools.

**UI Structure and Context:**
The window title bar reads "Egress Settings." The left pane contains the instructional text: "Select an item to view its description." The primary configuration content is presented in the right pane as a two-column list view control with headers: "Setting" and "State."

**Setting List Details:**
The list displays 24 configurable items, with configuration status categorized primarily as "Enabled" or "Not configured."

*   **Groupings/Folders:** The first two entries, "Classifier Addins" and "Workspace Addins," are represented by folder icons, suggesting sub-settings or categories. They do not have a listed "State."
*   **Enabled Policies (Examples):** Settings currently active include "Egress Resiliency," "Hide System Tray," "Load Behaviour Addin - Outlook," "Manifest - Outlook Addin," and "Run Tray For User."
*   **Not Configured Policies (Examples):** The majority of settings are listed as "Not configured." These include "Email Enforcement," all options related to "Large File Attach" (32 bit, 64 bit, Bar, Max KB, Min KB, Mode), and several Outlook UI customization options (e.g., "Outlook Disable Categories," "Outlook Disable Restrictions Button").
*   **Configuration Status Count:** Five settings are listed as "Enabled," and 17 settings are listed as "Not configured."

A list of policy options will be displayed in this folder.

images.alt:
The image displays the configuration window for the "Egress Resiliency" policy, likely within a Group Policy Management Editor or administrative tool.

**UI Elements and Configuration Status:**

*   **Window Title:** Egress Resiliency.
*   **Navigation:** Contains "Previous Setting" and "Next Setting" buttons.
*   **Policy Status:** The policy is currently set to **Enabled** via radio button selection. Options also include "Not Configured" and "Disabled."
*   **Metadata Fields:**
    *   A multi-line text box is provided for a "Comment."
    *   A read-only field labeled "Supported on" contains the text: "Supported on version 4.2 and above of Egress Client."

**Configuration Options:**

*   **Options Section:** Under the label "EgressResiliency," a numeric input field is present with the value **1**.
*   **Help Section (Context):** The associated help text details the function of this setting:
    > "Prevents users from disabling Egress if they do not have admin privileges. This will need to be set as 1 to stop users from disabling Egress."
images.context: ook add-in and prevent users from disabling it, the value should be set to 1.

images.alt:
This image displays the configuration dialog for the "Load Behaviour Addin - Outlook" setting, likely within a policy management interface.

**Configuration Status and Context:**
*   The primary setting is configured using three radio buttons: "Not Configured," "Enabled," and "Disabled." **"Enabled" is currently selected.**
*   A multi-line text box labeled "Comment" is provided for administrator notes (currently empty).
*   A read-only field labeled "Supported on:" displays the requirement: "Supported on version 4.0 and above of Egress Client."
*   The dialog features navigation controls: "Previous Setting" and "Next Setting" buttons.

**Options and Help Panel:**
*   **Options:** Under the "Options:" heading, the parameter "Load behaviour of the Egress Outlook Addin" is managed via a dropdown selection menu, currently displaying **"3 = Enable."**
*   **Help:** The accompanying "Help:" text box specifies the function: "Specifies the load behaviour of the Addin. This helps Outlook to see if the Addin has crashed or is working normally. By default this is set to 3."

This image displays a configuration dialog box titled **"Manifest - Outlook Addin,"** designed for managing policy settings for an add-in, likely related to the Egress client.

**Key UI Elements and Configuration:**

1.  **Title and Navigation:** The window is titled "Manifest - Outlook Addin." Navigation controls include **"Previous Setting"** and **"Next Setting."**
2.  **Add-in Status:** The configuration status is set via radio buttons. The option **"Enabled"** is currently selected, while "Not Configured" and "Disabled" are unchecked. A corresponding "Comment" field is present but empty.
3.  **Support Context:** A read-only field labeled **"Supported on:"** specifies the compatibility requirement: **"Supported on version 4.0 and above of Egress Client."**
4.  **Manifest Configuration (Options):** Under the "Options" heading, a path is defined for the Manifest file: `file:///C:\Program Files (x86)\Egress\Swit...` (path truncated).
5.  **Help/Description:** The associated "Help" field provides context regarding policy application and registry keys: **"Choose to remove the registry key from HKLM but turn on for specific users."**
